prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 1
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 2
Name: Bronco Knight
Description: A former bodyguard who killed his team leader. He is set to stand trial soon.
Character 3
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A defense attorney I have known for a long time, but haven't seen in years. Apparently, he lived abroad for a while.
Character 4
Name: Rocco Carcerato
Description: An inmate and former boxer who is obsessed with training. Has a pet polar bear named Teddy.
Character 5
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 6
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: A rookie prosecutor who's taken over my cases on the Committee's orders.
Character 7
Name: Simeon Saint
Description: The suspect in this case. A timid young man who seems an unlikely murderer.
Character 8
Name: Fifi Laguarde
Description: Warden of the prison. An animal lover who considers physical contact to be very important.
Character 9
Name: Frank Sahwit
Description: The prison inmate who first discovered the body. Currently training to be a pet stylist.
Character 10
Name: Bodhidharma Kanis
Description: A blind ex-assassin whose favored tools were a black dog and a knife. The tinkling of small bells used to accompany his appearance.
Character 11
Name: Shi-Long Lang
Description: An Interpol agent with an unrivaled arrest rate. Originally from Zheng Fa.
Character 12
Name: Regina Berry
Description: Head animal trainer at the Berry Big Circus, and Saint's boss.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 1
Name: Building Layout
Description: A map of the facility, including the detention center and the prison proper.
Evidence 2
Name: Mr. Knight's Body
Description: Cause of death: Stab wound to the throat. Death would have been instant. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. [info] The victim had a ring on his right hand, which was covered by a sheet when the body was discovered.  Killed instantly by a stab wound to the throat. The body is covered in dirt. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. Killed instantly by a stab wound to the throat. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. A sweet scent can be detected.
Evidence 3
Name: Pocket Chess Set
Description: A folding chessboard with the pieces stored inside. It appears to have belonged to the victim. A folding chessboard with the pieces stored inside. It belonged to Knight, and was brought to him at his request by Saint. Portable folding chessboard. Belonged to Knight. There is a hidden space inside the chessboard. Knight hid a chisel in here to prevent it from being found by the prison staff.
Evidence 4
Name: Rubber Glove
Description: Only one glove was found at the crime scene. Prison-issued equipment for working inmates. Stained with blood and mud. Found in Workshop A. Used by Sahwit when he was doing his animal styling training. Stained with blood and mud. Found in Workshop A. Sullied after being worn by Sahwit when administering a dark mudpack treatment. Also bloodstained.
Evidence 5
Name: Rope
Description: Discovered on top of Knight's body. Does this mean the victim was tied up?
Evidence 6
Name: Bloodstained Sheet
Description: Colorful tarp found by the victim's body. Some of these were being stored in Workshop A.
Evidence 7
Name: Door Sensor
Description: Fitted to each workshop's door, they detect and react to the prisoners' bracelets when they are near by raising the alarm. They open the doors if an animal is detected, but raise the alarm if an inmate's bracelet is detected. Prisoners are not allowed to move about freely.
Evidence 8
Name: Prison Roll Call
Description: Held three times a day: 7 AM, noon, and 9 PM. The victim's body had not been found at the time of the 7 AM roll call.
Evidence 9
Name: Black Dog
Description: Sahwit claims to have seen this dog biting the victim's throat. He doesn't seem to like me very much.
Evidence 10
Name: Sahwit's Bracelet
Description: Sahwit's bracelet is broken, and can no longer be detected by the prison's sensors. Sahwit's bracelet wasn't working at the time of the incident, and could not be detected by the sensors.
Evidence 11
Name: Dog Chess Piece
Description: Carved for fun by Kanis. He also seems to be engaged in correspondence chess via postal mail.
Evidence 12
Name: Prison Search
Description: Winner, Gavèlle and the warden searched the prison for the murder weapon, but couldn't find anything.
Evidence 13
Name: Wiped Floor
Description: There are signs that the floor in the victim's detention center cell was wiped clean. There are signs that the floor in the victim's cell was wiped clean. I've ordered a test to see if it was blood. There are signs that blood was wiped from the floor of the victim's cell. We're currently checking whose blood it is. There are signs that blood was wiped from the floor of the victim's cell. The blood has been confirmed as Knight's.
Evidence 14
Name: Chess Diagram
Description: The positions of the pieces match those on the board in Kanis's cell. Knight was playing correspondence chess against Kanis. Did the two have some sort of connection?
Evidence 15
Name: Security Camera Footage
Description: Footage of a detention center holding cell showing the victim being attacked by a dark form. The time stamp is off due to a three-hour gap in the footage. This was actually recorded around 9 AM.
Evidence 16
Name: Missing Guard Uniform
Description: Stolen from a guard's locker in the detention center corridor on March 26th.
Evidence 17
Name: Mr. Knight's Cell Key
Description: A guard was attacked and his keys, including the one to Knight's cell, were stolen. They have yet to be recovered. A guard was attacked the day before the murder, and his keys were stolen. They were found in Carcerato's possession.
Evidence 18
Name: Security Gates
Description: Deployed at the entrances to both the detention center and the prison proper. Capable of detecting items made of metal.
Evidence 19
Name: Tunnel Prints
Description: A photo of the tunnel between the prison and the detention center. It seems to depict the paw prints of a dog. A photo of the tunnel between the prison and the detention center. Shows paw prints made by a bear.
Evidence 20
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The interim report suggests that the cause of death was a stab wound to the neck, inflicted by a sharp blade. Death was instantaneous. Estimated time of death is between 3 AM and 6 AM on the 27th. Instant death from a stab wound to the neck.
Evidence 21
Name: Chisel
Description: Contains traces of blood. Hidden by Kanis inside his dog's mouth. Has a small bell attached to it. Belonged to Knight. Hidden by Kanis in Helmut's mouth in order to avoid suspicion.
Evidence 22
Name: Mr. Kanis's Bells
Description: Only two such bells exist. One is attached to Helmut the dog, the other to Kanis's knife, which was seized by the police during his arrest.
Evidence 23
Name: Mr. Saint's Trick
Description: A contraption that used the well, a very heavy weight, three pulleys, and two lengths of rope to send Saint flying during the show. Used during the show to send Saint flying. The weights were replaced with the victim's body by someone.
Evidence 24
Name: Breakers
Description: Located in the power room, just off the prison yard. Were they tampered with the night before the body was found?

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Recreation time ended around 10 AM.
Person: Elbird
Testimony 1
Testimony: I returned to this room and went straight to my training.
Person: Elbird
Testimony 2
Testimony: Just as I'd counted to two, I heard a voice shout out, "AAARGH! I've been stabbed!"
Person: Elbird
Testimony 3
Testimony: It sounded like someone in pain, calling out for help. But...
Person: Elbird
Testimony 4
Testimony: I couldn't do anything since I was locked up in my cell. So, I went back to my training.
Person: Elbird

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. First, I'll go through each evidence and testimony to see where there might be conflicting information.

Looking at the testimonies provided by Elbird (Testimonies 0-4). The key points from Elbird's testimonies are:

- Testimony 0: Recreation time ended around 10 AM.
- Testimony 1: Returned to the room and went straight to training.
- Testimony 2: Heard a voice shout "AAARGH! I've been stabbed!" after counting to two.
- Testimony 3: It sounded like someone in pain, but...
- Testimony 4: Couldn't do anything because locked in cell, so went back to training.

Now, looking at the evidence. Let's see which evidence might conflict with these testimonies.

Evidence 20 (Autopsy Report) states the estimated time of death is between 3 AM and 6 AM on the 27th. The security camera footage (Evidence 15) was recorded around 9 AM but had a timestamp gap, so the attack might have happened around 9 AM. Wait, but the autopsy says death was between 3-6 AM. That's a conflict here. The camera footage suggests the attack was at 9 AM, but the autopsy says death was earlier. So Evidence 15 and 20 might conflict, but the question is about evidence and testimony contradicting each other, not evidence vs evidence.

Looking at Elbird's testimony 2: He heard the shout at the moment he counted to two, after returning to his training. Since he says recreation time ended at 10 AM (Testimony 0), and he went back to training after that (Testimony 1), the time he heard the shout would be after 10 AM. But the autopsy (Evidence 20) says death was between 3-6 AM, which is way earlier. So if Elbird heard the victim's shout at 10 AM, but the victim was already dead by then, that's a contradiction. 

Wait, but the security camera footage (Evidence 15) says the attack was recorded around 9 AM, which is after 3-6 AM. However, the autopsy's time of death is 3-6 AM, so the attack would have to occur during that window. If Elbird heard the shout at 10 AM, that would be after the estimated time of death, making his testimony conflicting with the autopsy. 

Therefore, Testimony 2 (Elbird hearing the shout at 10 AM) contradicts Evidence 20 (time of death 3-6 AM). Because if the person was stabbed and died by 6 AM, they couldn't be shouting in pain at 10 AM. 

Alternatively, maybe the timestamp on the camera was off by three hours, so the actual attack time was 9 AM (as per the corrected timestamp), which would fall within the autopsy's 3-6 AM? Wait no, 9 AM is after 6 AM. Wait the evidence says the timestamp was off by three hours, so the footage was actually recorded around 9 AM, meaning the attack happened then. But the autopsy says death was between 3-6 AM. So that's a conflict between Evidence 15 and 20. But the question is about evidence and testimony. 

Alternatively, Elbird's testimony 2 says he heard the shout when he was in his cell after returning from recreation (which ended at 10 AM). So the shout was at 10 AM, but the victim was already dead by then according to the autopsy. Therefore, the testimony (Testimony 2) and Evidence 20 contradict each other. 

So the answer would be Testimony 2 and Evidence 20.
</think>

Wait, looking at Testimony 3, he says he saw the man dead. If the murder weapon was the chisel, but the stab wound is consistent with that. No contradiction there. 

Hmm, maybe I'm missing something obvious. Let me check the first user's answer in the previous interaction. They had Evidence 20 (Autopsy Report) and Testimony 2. But in this new problem, the testimonies are from Sahwit, so maybe a different pair.

Wait, Testimony 0 says Sahwit was in the workroom practicing skills. Evidence 4 says the rubber glove was used by him during his training. That's consistent.

Wait, Testimony 3 says he saw the dead man. If the body was covered by a sheet (Evidence 2), maybe he couldn't see it? But the sheet was over the body, but he could still see it's a body.

Ah! That's a key point. Let me check again.

Wait, Testimony 1 says Sahwit went to the adjacent workroom's door and peeked through the window, seeing the body there. But according to Evidence 2, the body was in Knight's detention center cell, not in a workroom. So the location is conflicting.

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 1
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 2
Name: Bronco Knight
Description: A former bodyguard who killed his team leader. He is set to stand trial soon.
Character 3
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A defense attorney I have known for a long time, but haven't seen in years. Apparently, he lived abroad for a while.
Character 4
Name: Rocco Carcerato
Description: An inmate and former boxer who is obsessed with training. Has a pet polar bear named Teddy.
Character 5
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 6
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: A rookie prosecutor who's taken over my cases on the Committee's orders.
Character 7
Name: Simeon Saint
Description: The suspect in this case. A timid young man who seems an unlikely murderer.
Character 8
Name: Fifi Laguarde
Description: Warden of the prison. An animal lover who considers physical contact to be very important.
Character 9
Name: Frank Sahwit
Description: The prison inmate who first discovered the body. Currently training to be a pet stylist.
Character 10
Name: Bodhidharma Kanis
Description: A blind ex-assassin whose favored tools were a black dog and a knife. The tinkling of small bells used to accompany his appearance.
Character 11
Name: Shi-Long Lang
Description: An Interpol agent with an unrivaled arrest rate. Originally from Zheng Fa.
Character 12
Name: Regina Berry
Description: Head animal trainer at the Berry Big Circus, and Saint's boss.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 1
Name: Building Layout
Description: A map of the facility, including the detention center and the prison proper.
Evidence 2
Name: Mr. Knight's Body
Description: Cause of death: Stab wound to the throat. Death would have been instant. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. [info] The victim had a ring on his right hand, which was covered by a sheet when the body was discovered.  Killed instantly by a stab wound to the throat. The body is covered in dirt. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. Killed instantly by a stab wound to the throat. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. A sweet scent can be detected.
Evidence 3
Name: Pocket Chess Set
Description: A folding chessboard with the pieces stored inside. It appears to have belonged to the victim. A folding chessboard with the pieces stored inside. It belonged to Knight, and was brought to him at his request by Saint. Portable folding chessboard. Belonged to Knight. There is a hidden space inside the chessboard. Knight hid a chisel in here to prevent it from being found by the prison staff.
Evidence 4
Name: Rubber Glove
Description: Only one glove was found at the crime scene. Prison-issued equipment for working inmates. Stained with blood and mud. Found in Workshop A. Used by Sahwit when he was doing his animal styling training. Stained with blood and mud. Found in Workshop A. Sullied after being worn by Sahwit when administering a dark mudpack treatment. Also bloodstained.
Evidence 5
Name: Rope
Description: Discovered on top of Knight's body. Does this mean the victim was tied up?
Evidence 6
Name: Bloodstained Sheet
Description: Colorful tarp found by the victim's body. Some of these were being stored in Workshop A.
Evidence 7
Name: Door Sensor
Description: Fitted to each workshop's door, they detect and react to the prisoners' bracelets when they are near by raising the alarm. They open the doors if an animal is detected, but raise the alarm if an inmate's bracelet is detected. Prisoners are not allowed to move about freely.
Evidence 8
Name: Prison Roll Call
Description: Held three times a day: 7 AM, noon, and 9 PM. The victim's body had not been found at the time of the 7 AM roll call.
Evidence 9
Name: Black Dog
Description: Sahwit claims to have seen this dog biting the victim's throat. He doesn't seem to like me very much.
Evidence 10
Name: Sahwit's Bracelet
Description: Sahwit's bracelet is broken, and can no longer be detected by the prison's sensors. Sahwit's bracelet wasn't working at the time of the incident, and could not be detected by the sensors.
Evidence 11
Name: Dog Chess Piece
Description: Carved for fun by Kanis. He also seems to be engaged in correspondence chess via postal mail.
Evidence 12
Name: Prison Search
Description: Winner, Gavèlle and the warden searched the prison for the murder weapon, but couldn't find anything.
Evidence 13
Name: Wiped Floor
Description: There are signs that the floor in the victim's detention center cell was wiped clean. There are signs that the floor in the victim's cell was wiped clean. I've ordered a test to see if it was blood. There are signs that blood was wiped from the floor of the victim's cell. We're currently checking whose blood it is. There are signs that blood was wiped from the floor of the victim's cell. The blood has been confirmed as Knight's.
Evidence 14
Name: Chess Diagram
Description: The positions of the pieces match those on the board in Kanis's cell. Knight was playing correspondence chess against Kanis. Did the two have some sort of connection?
Evidence 15
Name: Security Camera Footage
Description: Footage of a detention center holding cell showing the victim being attacked by a dark form. The time stamp is off due to a three-hour gap in the footage. This was actually recorded around 9 AM.
Evidence 16
Name: Missing Guard Uniform
Description: Stolen from a guard's locker in the detention center corridor on March 26th.
Evidence 17
Name: Mr. Knight's Cell Key
Description: A guard was attacked and his keys, including the one to Knight's cell, were stolen. They have yet to be recovered. A guard was attacked the day before the murder, and his keys were stolen. They were found in Carcerato's possession.
Evidence 18
Name: Security Gates
Description: Deployed at the entrances to both the detention center and the prison proper. Capable of detecting items made of metal.
Evidence 19
Name: Tunnel Prints
Description: A photo of the tunnel between the prison and the detention center. It seems to depict the paw prints of a dog. A photo of the tunnel between the prison and the detention center. Shows paw prints made by a bear.
Evidence 20
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The interim report suggests that the cause of death was a stab wound to the neck, inflicted by a sharp blade. Death was instantaneous. Estimated time of death is between 3 AM and 6 AM on the 27th. Instant death from a stab wound to the neck.
Evidence 21
Name: Chisel
Description: Contains traces of blood. Hidden by Kanis inside his dog's mouth. Has a small bell attached to it. Belonged to Knight. Hidden by Kanis in Helmut's mouth in order to avoid suspicion.
Evidence 22
Name: Mr. Kanis's Bells
Description: Only two such bells exist. One is attached to Helmut the dog, the other to Kanis's knife, which was seized by the police during his arrest.
Evidence 23
Name: Mr. Saint's Trick
Description: A contraption that used the well, a very heavy weight, three pulleys, and two lengths of rope to send Saint flying during the show. Used during the show to send Saint flying. The weights were replaced with the victim's body by someone.
Evidence 24
Name: Breakers
Description: Located in the power room, just off the prison yard. Were they tampered with the night before the body was found?

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: There is a rather well-known technique among the prisoners here...
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 1
Testimony: If the hand with the bracelet stays in the room, you can step out without sounding the alarm.
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 2
Testimony: That's how I was able to peek into the adjacent room.
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 3
Testimony: The moment I realized that the man inside was dead, I let out a scream.
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 4
Testimony: And to my horror, there was a black dog biting his neck!
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 5
Testimony: He most likely had passed away already. His hands moved nary an inch...
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 6
Testimony: The ring with the snowflake insignia glimmered, with no purpose but to catch my eye.
Person: Sahwit

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through each piece of evidence and testimony carefully.

First, let's look at the testimonies provided by Sahwit. Testimony 0 mentions a technique where prisoners can leave a room by keeping their bracelet inside, allowing them to step out without triggering the alarm. Testimony 1 elaborates on this method. Testimony 2 says that's how Sahwit peeked into the adjacent room. 

Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 7 (Door Sensor) states that the doors open for animals but raise an alarm if a prisoner's bracelet is detected. It also mentions that prisoners aren't allowed to move freely. If Sahwit's testimony is true about bypassing the alarm by leaving the bracelet in the room, that would mean the sensor wasn't triggered. But according to Evidence 7, the sensors are supposed to detect the bracelet and raise an alarm if a prisoner is near. So if Sahwit left his bracelet in the room and moved, the sensor should have detected it when he approached the door, right? Because the bracelet is still in the room, but he's moving outside. Wait, maybe I need to think again. The testimony says the hand with the bracelet stays in the room, so maybe the bracelet is still in the room's detection area. But the door sensors detect when the bracelet is near. If the bracelet is inside the room, moving to the adjacent room's door would mean the bracelet is no longer near that door's sensor. Hmm, this is a bit confusing. Let me re-examine the exact wording.

Evidence 7 says the doors detect prisoners' bracelets when near, raising an alarm. So if Sahwit left his bracelet in the original room, moving to another door would not trigger that door's sensor because his bracelet isn't near it. Wait, maybe the technique allows them to move between rooms by keeping the bracelet in one room while moving to another, but the sensors on each door would only trigger if the bracelet is near that specific door. So if he's in the next room without his bracelet near the door sensor, then maybe he can get through. But the problem is that the bracelet is still in the first room. The sensors on the first door would have been triggered when he left, right? Because when he exits, the bracelet is still in the first room, so the door sensor there would detect it. Maybe the method is to have someone else hold the bracelet or keep it in a way that it's not near the door sensors when moving. Alternatively, maybe the technique is a flaw in the system that Sahwit is exploiting. However, according to Evidence 7's description, the system is designed to prevent prisoners from moving freely unless they have an animal. So if Sahwit's testimony claims he used this method to enter another room without triggering the alarm, that directly contradicts the Door Sensor's functionality as described in Evidence 7, which says that inmate bracelets cause alarms. Therefore, if the sensors are supposed to alarm whenever a bracelet is near, then Sahwit's method of leaving the bracelet in the room and moving would still have the bracelet in the original room's vicinity, thus triggering the alarm when approaching another door. Or maybe the sensors only check when approaching a door, so if he's in another room without the bracelet near that door's sensor, it wouldn't trigger. But the testimony's method suggests that the bracelet is in the original room, so moving to another room's door wouldn't have the bracelet near that door's sensor. The problem is that the Door Sensor's description says prisoners can't move freely, implying that the system works to prevent such movement. If Sahwit's testimony is true, then the system has a loophole, contradicting Evidence 7's assertion that the sensors effectively prevent free movement. Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 7 and Testimony 1 or 2. Let me check the exact testimony numbers again. The user's input has Testimonies 0-6. Testimony 1 says, "If the hand with the bracelet stays in the room, you can step out without sounding the alarm." Testimony 2 says that's how he peeked into the adjacent room. Evidence 7's description says the doors raise an alarm if an inmate's bracelet is detected. So according to Evidence 7, the system should prevent that by alarming when the bracelet is near. But Sahwit's testimony claims he bypassed it. That's a contradiction. So the conflicting pair is Evidence 7 and Testimony 1. Alternatively, maybe Testimony 2. Wait, the user's last example had Testimony 2 contradicting Evidence 2. Let me confirm the exact numbers here. The current Testimonies are numbered 0-6. The user's previous examples had different testimony numbers, but in this case, Testimony 1 is the one explaining the technique. So the contradiction is between Evidence 7 (Door Sensor's functionality) and Testimony 1 (the technique allowing bypass). Therefore, the answer should be evidence 7 and testimony 1.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let me tackle this problem step by step. The user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and I need to find a pair where an evidence contradicts a testimony. The answer should be just one pair in JSON format.

First, I'll go through each testimony and see if there's any evidence that conflicts with it. The testimonies here are from someone named Debeste, which isn't listed in the characters, but maybe that's okay. Let's look at each testimony:

Testimony 0: "So, you want to know my reasons for arresting that man?" – Just stating intent, not conflicting.

Testimony 1: "Obviously, we had a fatal reason for arresting Simeon!" – Vague, no direct contradiction yet.

Testimony 2: "The answer is simple. Yes. We found 'traces' of that guy over there." – "Traces" could refer to fingerprints or other evidence.

Testimony 3: "The victim carried a chessboard. From it, we found Simeon Saint's fingerprints." – This is key. The testimony claims that the chessboard had Simeon's fingerprints.

Testimony 4: "How's that? Perfectly simple, perfectly decisive... Right?" – Rhetorical question, no contradiction here.

Testimony 5: "The other prints belonged to the victim and the guards. Yes, only Simeon's prints are unnatural!" – Again, mentions fingerprints on the chessboard.

Testimony 6: "Of course, I was the first to notice it because I'm the Best." – Boasting, not conflicting.

Testimony 7: "My reasoning is faster than light. It'd take you a light year to get it. In short, I am the Best!" – More boasting.

Now, looking at the evidences, Evidence 3 (Pocket Chess Set) says: "It belonged to Knight, and was brought to him at his request by Saint." So Saint brought the chessboard to Knight. If Saint brought it, then his fingerprints would naturally be on it, right? But the testimony claims that Simeon's fingerprints being there are "unnatural," implying they shouldn't be there. Wait, but if Saint brought it to Knight, then his fingerprints would be expected. So the testimony's claim that the fingerprints are "unnatural" contradicts that, because they should be there. Therefore, the testimony (Testimony 3) is wrong because the chessboard was indeed brought by Saint, so his fingerprints would be natural, not unnatural. So the contradiction is between Evidence 3 and Testimony 3. 

Alternatively, maybe the evidence says that the chessboard was the victim's, so if Saint brought it, but the testimony says that Saint's prints are there, but maybe the evidence states that the chessboard was the victim's, so Saint's prints might not be expected. Wait, the evidence says "It belonged to Knight, and was brought to him at his request by Saint." So Saint gave it to Knight, so Saint's fingerprints would be on it. The testimony says that Simeon's (Saint's) prints were found and that they're "unnatural," meaning they shouldn't be there. But according to Evidence 3, Saint bringing it would mean his prints are natural. Hence, contradiction between Evidence 3 and Testimony 3.

Another point: Testimony 3 says that the other prints were victim and guards, and only Saint's were "unnatural." But if Saint brought the chessboard, then his prints would be normal. So that's a contradiction. So the answer should be Evidence 3 and Testimony 3. Let me check other possibilities to be sure.

Looking at Evidence 14: Chess Diagram mentions that Knight was playing correspondence chess with Kanis, so Kanis might have his prints too, but the testimony mentions only Saint's prints as unnatural. But the main point is the testimony claims Saint's prints are unnatural, but the evidence implies they should be there because he brought the chessboard. So yes, that's the contradiction.
</think>
